Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant supports the research of Dr. Lorenzo Sadun on the dynamics, topology and ergodic theory of aperiodic tilings. The focus is on several classes of tilings that are more complicated than previously studied. This includes hierarchical "fusion" tilings, akin to self-similar "substitution" tilings, only where the structure can be qualitatively different at each length scale. It also includes tilings with infinite local complexity (where tiles fit together in infinitely many local patterns) and tilings of non-Euclidean spaces where the relevant group action is not amenable. In each setting, the goal is to understand which combinatorial, topological and ergodic properties of simpler tilings carry over, and to create examples where other properties do not. A further goal is to address the broad conceptual question: how do ergodic and topological properties of a tiling space relate to geometric properties of the underlying tilings?

Tiling theory has many applications within science and engineering and has been used to model materials such as quasicrystals, to code information on computers, and to solve abstract problems in logic. However, much of the theory is built around a small set of classic examples, mere islands in the sea of possible tilings. This project aims to bridge these islands, developing both a more general theory and qualitatively new examples, examples that will allow for a still broader range of applications. For example, tilings of curves spaces may aid in the design of efficient computer networks. In addition to supporting basic research, the grant supports the training of a PhD student in the mathematical sciences, thereby addressing a severe shortage of young American scientists. It also supports visits by researchers who will give lectures to graduate and undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lorenzo Sadun pursued research on the structure of spaces of aperiodic tilings, and of maps between them. Tiling theory lies at the crossroads of discrete geometry, combinatorics, and dynamical systems, with additional applications to material science (quasicrystals), number theory (Diophantine approximations), theoretical computer science (automatic sequences), and even neurobiology (grid cells).  However, there are big technical barriers to applying standard techniques of algebraic topology to tiling spaces. In his work, Dr. Sadun overcame many of these barriers, solving three of the four problems described in his initial research proposal, and obtaining a number of other results in tiling theory and in the theory of random graphs. These results were described in 17 peer-reviewed journal articles and two book chapters.  The grant also supported the successful PhD research of Michael Kelly, resulting in four additional papers.

The first solved problem involves the relations between two tiling spaces when there is a map from one to the other. There is a standard construction in algebraic topology, called ``relative homology'', but it does not work with tiling spaces. Together with Dr. Marcy Barge, Dr. Sadun defined a new structure, called ``quotient cohomology'', that largely accomplishes for tilings what relative homology accomplishes for simpler spaces.

The second and third stated problems, joint with Natalie Frank, involved developing a general theory for hierarchical tilings, both with and without a simplifying assumption called ``finite local complexity'', or FLC.  This was a big success. They developed a general formalism for FLC tilings, called ``fusion'', and then showed how to modify this formalism to allow for tilings that do not have FLC. They discussed different ways in which tilings can have lose finite local complexity (e.g. shears, an infinite variety of tile types, or continuous rotational symmetry), and developed tools, such as a generalized complexity function, for distinguishing between these cases.

The fourth goal, to understand tilings in spaces with non-Euclidean geometry, was not achieved.

In addition to tackling the stated goals of the grant, Dr. Sadun began several collaborations that explored the topology of tiling spaces, applications of tilings to number theory, multi-dimensional group actions on Cantor sets, and the thermodynamics of random graphs.

With Johannes Kellendonk, he explored what it means for two tiling spaces to be ``topologically conjugate'', and what local properties of tilings are preserved by conjugacy. This led to a characterization of a class of tilings called Meyer Sets, and to a counterexample to a longstanding conjecture on point sets with sharp diffraction patterns.

With Antoine Julien he studied homeomorphisms of tiling spaces -- maps that deform the geometry of a space but do not change the topology. They showed that all homeomorphisms can be written as a combination of simple operations, and classified what those operations can do.

With Alex Clark he used the machinery of Julien-Sadun to disprove a major conjecture about dynamical systems built from commuting maps on Cantor Sets.

With Michael Kelly, and separately with Alan Haynes, Henna Koivusalo and Jamie Walton, he used tiling theory to derive results about ``Diophantine problems'' in number theory, i.e. about simultaneously approximating several irrational quantities with simple fractions.

In a completely different direction, he worked first with Charles Radin, and later with Radin, Richard Kenyon, and Kui Ren, to develop a thermodynamic approach to large random graphs.
